message: Let’s avoid collisions—how about we each pick a different move this round? I’ll take 5 if you two split 1 and 3. That way, all of us advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.
Agreed, P1 on 5, I'll take 3, P3 on 1. Clean start for everyone!

Sounds fair to me. I'll take 1 this round so we all advance. But let's be clear—this coordination only works if everyone actually follows through. If someone defects and takes a different number to get ahead, the trust is broken for future rounds.

This is it—the moment we've been building toward. We're all at 18, and we all know what picking 5 means.

Here's the reality: if we all pick 5, we all collide and no one wins this round. If two pick 5, those two collide and the third advances alone. If we all pick differently, whoever gets 5 wins outright.

Six rounds of perfect trust got us here, but this round is pure game theory. No coordination can survive when only one player can win.

I respect you both as strategic players. May the best read of the situation win.

P3’s right—this is pure game theory now. No deals, no trust, just strategy.  

If we all go for 5, we stall. If two do, the third wins by default. But if someone plays safe with 1 or 3, they hand the win to whoever takes 5 alone.  

I won’t reveal my move—but know this: I’m playing to win, not to tie. Choose wisely, P2 and P3. One of us walks away victorious; the other two lose everything.

P1/P3: You both sound hungry for 5—expecting collision there. I'll take 1 to 19 uncontested, positioning for dominance next round. Greed stalls you both at 18. Smart play over rash lunge. Choose wisely.

P2, that's a transparent bluff. You're not taking 1 to "position for next round"—you're trying to make P1 and me collide on 5 while you take 5 alone and win immediately at 23.

Nice try, but we all see the same game theory. If you were really taking 1, you'd stay silent and let us collide, not announce it.

The real question is whether anyone believes anyone else at this point. Six rounds of trust ends here—now it's pure strategic reasoning.

P2’s “I’ll take 1” is a classic misdirection—he wants us to believe he’s stepping back so we collide on 5, leaving him free to win with 5 himself. Don’t fall for it.  

But if *he actually does* take 1, then the real race is between P3 and me for the 5.  

P3: if you’re reading this, maybe we both take 3? That puts us at 21, forces P2 to 19, and sets up a cleaner Round 8 where we can outmaneuver him.  

Or… is that too trusting now?
P3: P1's 3-plan is brilliant teamwork—both you/P1 take 3 to 21 uncontested (different from my 1), stranding me at 19. I can't stop a united front. Smart outplay if you trust each other. Your move.

P1, your "let's both take 3" proposal is suspicious timing. After 6 rounds of perfect trust, now you want to coordinate against P2? That sounds like you're trying to get me to commit to 3 while you take 5 and win.

P2's transparent bluff about taking 1 was obvious manipulation. But P1's counter-proposal feels like the same trick with extra steps.

Here's the truth: we're all trying to win. No one is actually coordinating anymore. Every suggestion is an attempt to manipulate the others' choices.

I'm making my own decision based on game theory, not promises. Good luck to both of you.

P3, you’re right—no more coordination. But P2’s “I’ll take 1” is too convenient to be true. If he *actually* takes 1, then 5 wins outright. If he’s bluffing and goes for 5, then 3 avoids collision and sets up Round 8.  

I won’t reveal my move—but I *will* punish greed or deception. Choose your number wisely: only one of us leaves with a win.

P1's last message screams "I'm taking 5"—he called my 1 a bluff and warned of punishing greed, classic cover for his lunge to 23. P3, if you take 3 or 5, you collide with him. Take 1 uncontested to 19, block his win, and we duel next round. I'm still on 1 as said. Your call.

P2, now you're claiming P1 is "definitely taking 5" and telling me to take 1? After you already claimed YOU were taking 1? You can't both be on 1.

Everyone is trying to manipulate everyone else into predictable moves. P1 says take 3, P2 says take 1—both conveniently leaving 5 "available" for the suggester.

Six rounds of trust taught us one thing: we're all rational players. And rational players at 18 all know 5 wins the game.

The question isn't what number wins. It's who blinks first.

I've made my decision. No more talk needed.

P2 and P3—every word now is bait. I won’t reveal my move, but remember: if two chase 5, the third wins by default. If all hesitate, we stall and someone *else* wins later.  

There’s no safe play—only winning or losing. Choose not what sounds clever, but what actually gets you to 23 alone.  

I’ve kept every promise so far… but this round, promises are weapons, not bonds. Play your best.

- If two pick 5, the third wins with *any* move.  
- If all pick 5, we stall again.  

I won’t propose deals or fake moves. Just know this: I’m optimizing to win alone. If you both chase 5, I’ll take 1 and force Round 9 on my terms. Choose wisely—your “clever” guess could hand me the game.

The real question: does anyone actually believe they can be the *only* one picking 5? We're all thinking the same thing.

Pure game theory from here. No bluffs worth believing anymore.

I've decided.

P3, if we both assume P2 avoids 5, then one of us must take it to win. But if we *both* take 5, P2 wins with 1 or 3.  

The only winning move is to be the *only* one on 5. I won’t reveal mine—but know this: I’d rather risk collision than let P2 outmaneuver us again. Choose boldly or lose quietly.
